ResponseText:
Who benefits from having data analysts in healthcare?

          As Etiowo explained in his presentation, through creating a database of information essentially, doctors can rely on that information to save time in their diagnosis. Being able to find trends in a patient's experience in comparison to others can be crucial in terms of when to address a stage in someone's condition. This gap in time is essential as a condition can be addressed too late, too early, not addressed at all, or addressed when not necessary. Improving the accuracy of these predictions can help instill better patient to doctor trust and improve hospital reputation overall. Doctors benefit because they can better direct their staff and communicate to patients and patients benefit through receiving appropriate care.

How does a career in data visualization align with your goals?

I actually went to an Industrial-Organizational (IO) Psychology connect event at Seattle Pacific University last night and I had a lengthy conversation with a PhD student about R. The event was essentially one of those student interest nights where we could talk with students in the masters and PhD programs, sample one of their classes, and question professors about the work they do. IO Psychologists essentially do an analysis of businesses to better improve organizational practices and employee engagement to maintain employee retention. It's a fairly new, but fast-growing field because of the high demand for company reconstruction.

IO Psychologists are usually called in as consultants to either create assessments or analyze from existing data to help make changes in a company. Data visualization is crucial as it serves as a means to better communicate the impact the data analysis may have for organizations. From what I've noticed is, most business practices have been summarized into simplified charts or visuals. It could possibly be used for the sake of efficiency as retaining information from a quick image is faster than memorizing a paragraph of information.

From what the PhD student told me, many companies are interested in hiring analysts who are familiar with R vs. SPSS because R is free and is flexible enough to be applied in many ways. She urged me to keep up with learning it because of how useful it is and I felt more inspired to keep going with it after talking with her.

I look forward to learning more with you. :)

What remaining question do you have about a career in data science?

What are the nuances between different skills? Like, are there specific jobs that require a skill level and how does pay vary depending on the skills you have?

Why is a data visualization career not appealing to many people?

I think, while crucial considering the mass amounts of unanalyzed data floating around and being held, people may not be interested in data visualization because of the grunt work required to get to that point. Making the pretty graphs seems easier than collecting the data, cleaning it, and then analyzing it. I remember when doing scouting in robotics in high school, I did the grunt work of manually inserting data into excel sheets after every match (you get sick of seeing 0s and 1s after a while), checking for issues in the data, and then handing over the clean set to our analyst so she could make the visualization and then someone else would present our data to other teams. No one wants to do that work. I remember staying up late some nights by myself rushing to get that data done just so someone could make a pretty picture of them and then people forgetting that there was more to the work that just the graphs at the end. I remember being turned off to this kind of work for a while because of how unrecognized it was and how time-consuming it is (I got sick often during competition season). But at the end of the day, seeing where the information goes and seeing how it helped people make decisions is what made it worth it.
